question.body: How do you think common treatments for rheumatoid arthritis affect the rest of the body?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Treatments for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) usually try to reduce the symptom of joint pain.

Correct. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) involves the body's own immune system attacking stressed cartilage. Thus, to treat RA, the immune system must be suppressed. With a weakened immune system, there is an increase risk of infection.
This is not quite right. Some hormonal therapies for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) can increase the risk of some types of fracture, but generally this is not an issue.
Incorrect. Lupus is another autoimmune disorder, and many times rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and lupus are treated the same way.

part.hint: how does homeostasis progress in normal tissue? Response to injury in the body attempts to move toward homeostasis.
